text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- Bulgaria's ruling Socialits should accept the opposition's demand for early parliamentary elections to stabilise the political situation in the country, parliament Speaker Blagovest Sendov told the state television. @

-- Bulgaria's opposition is planning to start a national political strike on Wednesday and 50,000 private taxi drivers were expected to block main roads in the country, Podkrepa trade union senior official told private Darik radio.
-- Some 80,000-90,000 Bulgarians attended a protest rally in Sofia on Sunday demanding early parliamentary elections, police officers said. @

-- Bulgaria's outgoing president Zhelyu Zhelev said he would give a mandate for the formation of a new government after the ruling Socialists and the opposition reach an agreement on holding early elections and on implementation of a joint programme to end the current economic crisis.
-- Bulgaria's president-elect Petar Stoyanov met with the U.S. ambassador and the Russian charge d'affaires in Sofia to discuss possible alternatives to end the political crisis in the country.
-- Bulgaria expects some $300 million in privatisation proceeds this year under a draft sell-off programme prepared by the outgoing Socialist government.

-- Damages inflicted to Bulgaria's parliament building during clashes between police and protesters on Friday and Saturday was estimated at some 500 million levs, parliament speaker Blagovest Sendov said.
